key_insight: A network-aware self-supervised learning model can learn high-content functional phenotypes directly from neuronal activity dynamics, enabling scalable screening for genetic modifiers without heavy labeling.
problem_solved: Existing screens struggle to capture subtle, network-level functional effects of genetic perturbations in neuronal dynamics and require extensive labeled data or hand-crafted features.
method: Incorporate network structure (functional/structural connectivity) into representation learning so dynamics are learned in a network-aware latent space.
Use self-supervised objectives (e.g., temporal contrastive/predictive tasks) on raw activity time series to learn rich phenotypic embeddings without labels.
Deploy a high-throughput pipeline that maps genetic perturbations to learned embeddings, then ranks/modulates candidate genetic modifiers by phenotypic shift.
impact: Provides ML practitioners a label-efficient framework to detect and quantify network-level functional phenotypes from time-series biological data, accelerating discovery of genetic modifiers and transferable to other dynamic systems.
visual_elements: Schematic of the model: raw neuronal activity + network matrix → network-aware encoder → phenotype embeddings
Example time-series traces showing baseline vs perturbed activity and corresponding embedding shifts
Embedding visualization (UMAP/t-SNE) with clusters for different genetic perturbations and highlighted modifiers
Heatmap or ranked bar chart linking genes to magnitude/type of phenotypic effect
paper_title: Network-aware self-supervised learning enables high-content phenotypic screening for genetic modifiers of neuronal activity dynamics
paper_authors: Parker Grosjean, Kaivalya Shevade, Cuong Nguyen, Sarah Ancheta, Karl Mader
